creator: daniel.fleischer@active-endpoints.com
daniel.fleischer@active-endpoints.com
text:
The problem I described only seems to occur when the Scheduler is used.  In my 
test I had Thread Group 2 & 3 set to delay their starts for 60 seconds.  My 
assumption was that Thread Group 1 would complete, then there'd be a 60 second 
delay until Thread Group 2 started.  It would complete and then there'd be a 
60 second delay until Thread Group 3 started.  While my assumption may be 
incorrect, the fact the the Loop count is ignored when the Scheduler is used 
is a problem.

When I unchecked the Scheduler from Thread Groups 2 & 3 and started the test 
all Thread Groups started at the same time and all performed the specified 
number of Loops.

creator: sebb@apache.org
text:
Works OK for me.

Did you set the end-time far enough ahead to allow the second and third thread
groups to complete? The end-time defaults to now...

Or did you set the duration (this overrides the end-time)?

creator: daniel.fleischer@active-endpoints.com
sebb@apache.org
text:
The startup delay only overrides the start time. It does not override the end-
time, see:

http://jakarta.apache.org/jmeter/usermanual/component_reference.html#Thread_Gro
up

The Start/End times in my Scheduler are all from March (I haven't used it in a 
while obviously).  So, since the end time has passed I guess it makes sense 
that it waits 60 seconds and then starts.  However, it still doesn't make any 
sense to me why it doesn't complete the specified number of Loops.

Why doesn't it complete the Loops?
creator: daniel.fleischer@active-endpoints.com
sebb@apache.org
text:
Because the end-time has been exceeded - it runs the first loop and then 
detects that it is time to stop.
